Award.AwardTitle: Energy-based Approach for Evaluating and Mitigating Liquefaction Potential

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for the development of an energy-based approach for evaluating the potential for liquefaction triggering and for designing remedial densification plans. The mechanically-based liquefaction evaluation procedure that will be developed as part of this study will build on existing macro-level, low-cycle, metal fatigue theories, using dissipated energy as its damage metric. The procedure will then be calibrated using field case histories and laboratory data in a Bayesian framework. Using dissipated energy (i.e., cumulative area bound by the shear-stress, shear-strain hysteresis loops) as a damage metric has physical significance. Energy is primarily dissipated in sandy soil that is subjected to shaking by inter-particle friction resulting from the relative movement of the sand particles (i.e., breakdown of the soil skeleton). Because the procedure will be based on well established fatigue theories, it will be easier to calibrate for conditions that do not have a strong presence in current liquefaction/non-liquefaction case history databases (e.g., high effective confining stresses and non-western U.S. ground motions). Additionally, the procedure will be able to evaluate liquefaction potential of soils subjected to motions other than those from earthquakes (e.g., construction vibrations, remedial densification techniques).
If successful, the results of this research will help minimize losses from earthquakes by improving the current methods for liquefaction risk assessment and mitigation. A procedure that can be confidently used to evaluate liquefaction potential in tectonic regimes other than active shallow crustal regions (i.e., in regions other than the western U.S., for example the central-eastern U.S.) will have direct impact on the engineering profession. The project is particularly timely as the nation renews its interest in nuclear power because most of the new plants will be located outside of the western U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project focused on the development of a new approach for evaluating the potential for liquefaction triggering. Liquefaction is a phenomenon that occurs in loose, saturated sandy soils subject to dynamic loading (e.g., earthquake shaking). Liquefaction has occurred in almost all previous major earthquakes and has result in significant damage to infrastructure (Figure 1). Shortcomings have been identified in the current state-of-practice approach for evaluating liquefaction potential and the inclusion of additional empirical correction factors to overcome these shortcomings has become onerous, and uncertainty exists about whether the correction factors actually overcome the shortcomings. The approach developed as part of this project is based on a metal fatigue theory framework (i.e., energy-based) and has several advantages over alternative approaches. For example, it is less empirical than the current state-of-practice approach, and as a result, can be used to evaluate liquefaction potential for scenarios that are not well represented in the liquefaction case history database with more confidence than the alternative procedures. The relevance of this is important, for example, due to the increase in induced earthquakes because the motions generated by these earthquakes have different characteristics than tectonic earthquakes.  

There are several broader impacts stemming from the proposed research. For society at large, the energy-based liquefaction evaluation procedure developed as part of this project will help minimize losses from earthquakes by improving the engineering community’s ability to assess risk due to liquefaction. Also, several students participated in performing research on this project. This exposed them to the challenges are rewards of performing research. As a direct result of this, one of the students decided to continue his studies to complete a Ph.D. degree, rather than his original plan to leave graduate school after completing his master’s degree. Also, this research entailed an international collaboration with the University of Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand. This exposed the students to researchers from across the world and allowed them to understand alternative approaches to performing research.
